caugi

Causal Graph Interface (for R) â€” a fast, tidyverseâ€‘friendly toolbox for building, coercing and analysing causal graphs.

caugi (pronounced â€œcorgiâ€) wraps a highâ€‘performance C++ core in a pipeâ€‘friendly R interface. Convert between many graph formats, compose graphs with expressive infix operators, and run algorithms on large sparse matricesâ€¯â€”â€¯all without leaving the tidyverse.

Key features

ğŸš€ What Why it matters
Flexible coercion & formats as_caugi() ingests igraph, graphNEL, pcalg amat (CPDAG and PAG), sparse or dense (binary/integerâ€‘coded) matrices, and tidy edge lists. Reâ€‘use existing data structures; no tedious reâ€‘encoding.
PAG & mixedâ€‘graph support Native edge codes for PAGs (o->, o-o, o--) and bidirected/undirected edges. Analyse outputs of discovery algorithms like FCI or RFCI outâ€‘ofâ€‘theâ€‘box.
Readable syntax a %-->% b, b %<->% c â€¦ Write graphs exactly as you draw them on a whiteboard.
Blazing speed Core Compressed Sparse Row (CSR) representation and algorithms in modern C++. Millions of edges? No problem.
Tidy output as_tibble() gives a tidy edge list that plugs straight into dplyr/tidyr. Analyse & visualise with your favourite tidy tools.
igraph interaction Use as_igraph() and analyse and convert back with as_caugi() on directed or undirected graphs. Seamlessly tap into igraphâ€™s ecosystem for directed or undirected graphs.

Installation 

# dev version from GitHub
install.packages("pak")         # if needed
pak::pak("frederikfabriciusbjerre/caugi")

# â€¦or wait for the first CRAN release
# install.packages("caugi")

caugi needs RÂ â‰¥Â 4.2 and a C++17â€‘capable compiler. See ?caugi::caugi for full details.

Quick start 

library(caugi)

my_graph <- caugi_graph(
  tibble::tibble(name = letters[1:4]),
  a %-->% b,
  b %<->% c,
  d %---% a
)

print(my_graph)
#> # A caugi_graph with 4 nodes and 3 edges
#>   from to edge_type
#> 1 a    b -->
#> 2 b    c <->
#> 3 a    d ---

Coercion works both ways:

ig <- igraph::make_ring(5, directed = TRUE)

cg <- as_caugi(ig)

How it works: compact CSR storage

Internally, every caugi_graph lives in Compressed Sparse Row (CSR) form:

row_ptr    : int[n_nodes + 1]
col_ids    : int[n_edges]
type_codes : int[n_edges]   # maps 1â€‘6 â†’ {"-->", "<->", â€¦}

Roadmap

Weâ€™re actively working on:

  • dâ€‘separation queries (dsep()).
  • Adjustmentâ€‘set identification (adjustment_sets()).
  • Graph distances â€” Structural Hamming Distance (SHD), simple Hamming Distance (HD), Adjustment Identification Distance (AID), and more!
  • Additional causal metrics and utilities.

Want to help? Open a discussion!

Contributing

Pull requests, issues and feature requests are welcome. Please open an issue before large changes.

Style guide

  • tidyverse style; run styler::style_pkg() before committing.
  • Each PR must pass devtools::check() with no errors, warnings, or notes.
